userreviews.userReview: English Nobility: Moral Debility, Spiritual Nihility Laughter would be bereaved if snobbery died.Peter UstinovThis pentalogy of semi-autobiographical novels by Edward St. Aubyn, published between 1992 and 2011, constitutes a devastatingly subtle shaming of modern-day British aristocracy--in a manner that could only be brilliantly accomplished by one of its own--and a troubling examination of the enduring destruction of child rape/abuse and the resulting substance abuse and addiction. A short synopsis of each of the 5 novels herein (in order of publication):NEVER MIND: Set in a mountain village in southeast France at the summer home of the protagonist Patrick when he was 5 years old. His dreadfully cruel father and meek alcoholic mother host several guests at a dinner party. Includes an incident of child rape.BAD NEWS: Patrick is now a 25-year-old heroin abuser in New York City to retrieve the ashes of his father over a 24-hour period. Includes probably the most accurate depiction of the mindset of a active drug addict I've ever read.SOME HOPE: Set back in England a few years later, prior to and at a society party, also takes place over a single day. Patrick is trying to stay clean and shares his secret with his best friend. A mordant observation of the haughty, shallow and cruel nature of the British upper crust. Queen Elizabeth's sister, Prince Margaret, plays a large and largely unflattering role.MOTHER'S MILK: This novel, unlike the first 3 and the last, all set on a single day, occurs over several years. It's almost as long as the first 3 combined. Patrick's 2 sons are born. For most of it, he's a self-centered cad, drunk and on pain pills. His mother has given away most of Patrick's legacy to a spiritual guide (see, e.g., Eggbart Tolle'). AT LAST: Patrick's mom's funeral. St. Aubyn really takes a sardonic whip to aristocracy concentrated in the form of a snot named Nicholas Pratt and his mother's sister. Example: Patrick's uncle comments on the charitable and warm nature of Patrick's mother, "Eleanor was always concerned about other people." "That can be a good thing," Nicholas admitted, "depending on who those other people are."Recommended. Particularly if you have any interest in the modern British aristocracy or a loved one with a drug addiction after suffering sexual abuse as a child.

Each of these novels is like a high-end entrée: exquisite and varied in flavor, yet unable on its own to satisfy the appetite. But together they provide complete satiation and not a hint of surfeit. St. Aubyn's sharp and justly-lauded prose is addicting; he manages to craft a story of the leading man least-deserving of your sympathy into something not only bleak and funny but oddly moving and genuine. One of the most enjoyable experiences I've had since reading Proust, who receives his fair share of nods in this modern masterstroke.

An unprecedented reading experience: 5-4-3-2-1. A tetralogy descending from audacious LOL greatness to who cares I think I'm gonna skim it. Of course I've read novels that started really strong and fizzled but never have they fizzled so evenly, their fizzle delineated by individually published volumes collected for the first time in a beautiful paperback with deckled edges and French flaps. The fizzle in my reading pleasure/engagement/interest I suppose matches the Melrose family's financial decline but that's way too generous an interpretation. The first novel is hardly much more than a novella but it's a zinger, the sort from which you read aloud passages to anyone nearby, bon mots forever, perfect images like killing ants with a cigar tip or making one's loved one kneel and eat fallen figs, all of it flowing and smart, charged with a bit of incestuous pedophilia, a few pages that create a shockwave that should've reverberated through these novels but really didn't. The second enjoyable novel (close third POV) takes place in NYC in the early '80s with Patrick a roving English Patrick Bateman junkie-type, not murderous but nihilistic. There's a wonderful image in the back of a cab imagining the lights in windows of passing office buildings as a crossword puzzle, but there's also a scene trying to buy heroin in Alphabet City that borders on cartoonish farce reminiscent, not in a good way, of The Confederacy of Dunces. By the third novel he's older, cleaned up, and ready to confess to a friend what happened as a child but the world around him opens up with a return to a roving third-person POV that never feels steady enough to jump from character to character at a posh dinner party. It's easy reading, relatively enjoyable, but becoming too diffuse, losing the focused psychological and emotional charge of the first two books. Everything in the final two novels dealing with Patrick's family, Patrick and his wife's affairs, and disinheritance and death of his mother felt sort of unnecessary, as though the supremely talented and intelligent and insightful writer of the first volume were coasting, letting the characters he'd created and new ones he concocted just spill out onto the page and do nothing more than talk. The charge or urgency of the first two books seemed replaced by always graceful but inconsistently worth-it verbosity, and so I felt nearly nothing for Patrick's dissolution into alcoholism or his mother's decline and death. Occasionally there were sentences or phrases I lingered over to appreciate ("psychedelic authority") but everything moved along on the skates of an automatic sort of semi-excellence. There's a fantastic story about his father as a young man on a wild boar hunt in India dispatching a man afflicted with rabies but it's too short and came too late to restore my love for this. The father David Melrose was a monster but so clever and so devilishly fucked-up it seemed like he needed to dominate things either on or off stage but he was dead by the beginning of the second novel and insufficiently sensed by the third one. Generally, in an ~850-page novel collection there wasn't enough devoted to David Melrose's youth, only a few pages really. These novels pretty much escaped David's gravity and/or seemed to fail to use his heft sufficiently, and also seemed not to remember themselves -- the Patrick of the last two books hardly seems to have shared the experiences of the abused boy or the young junkie. For a long story of the dissolution of a wealthy family, Thomas Mann's Buddenbrooks: The Decline of a Family seems like the reigning champ. Or at least I had it in my head as I read as a template/standard. Anyway, a great start that slowly but surely fizzled. Something else: it made me not want to write, like the author's prose was so consistently flowing and intelligent and descriptive and always readable but ultimately failed to really engage me in way that made me think toward the end why even bother with reading and writing? I first became interested in this book when I saw it suggested that A Little Life stole a lot from it and that this was in many ways superior -- the gray cover of the paperback also seems similar, as though the publishers wanted to capitalize on the association -- but really other than the fact that both central characters are victims of sexual abuse there's not much of a comparison to be made (A Little Life is, apparently very intentionally, the opposite of a family novel), particularly on a formal level but also Yanagihara's characters are so much stronger and the novel as a whole is so much steadier and unified, which makes sense of course since St. Aubyn's novels were published separately over time and Yanagihara's novel was written in a year and a half. I should also note that the inauguration occurred on the day I started the third novel and as we all know pretty much everything, particularly everyone's ability to concentrate, has gone downhill since then, so it's possible that the horrific reality show playing out recently at a granular level on Twitter warped my brain and hampered my ability to read the final three installments, but regardless I can proclaim with confidence that these volumes didn't offer a sufficiently strong immersive literary distraction since a certain fuckwit took an oath in front of the largest crowd ever assembled anywhere ever to undermine the Constitution and grab the world by its ya-ya.

Werkelijk ademloos en soms jubelend van bewondering heb ik achter elkaar alle Patrick Melrose romans gelezen, in het Engels overigens al schijnt de Nederlandse vertaling heel goed te zijn. Zelden heb ik zulk ongelofelijk geniaal proza gelezen, zelden heb ik boeken gelezen die zo zwartgallig waren en tegelijk zo oerkomisch, zelden heb ik een verhaal gelezen dat zo traumatisch was van inhoud en tegelijk zo enorm gepolijst van stijl en compositie. Ik ben heel vaak heel enthousiast over een boek, maar deze cyclus is echt van de buitencategorie: een meesterwerk, dat ik nog vaak wil herlezen.De inhoud van deze vijfdelige cyclus is op zich al pregnant: we volgen hoe de kleine Patrick wordt verkracht door zijn vader zonder te begrijpen wat er gebeurt, hoe Patrick als twintigjarige met allerlei innerlijke demonen vecht en vooral met een verslaving aan allerlei drugs (cocaïne, heroïne, later ook drank), en hoe Patrick als middelbare te kampen heeft met een mede door zijn innerlijke demonen strandend huwelijk en met levensbedreigende depressies. Dat zijn beide ouders tussendoor overlijden is dan nog een lichtpuntje. Kortom: zware en traumatische kost, zeker als je daarbij bedenkt dat de hele roman nog semi-autobiografisch is ook.Maar het geniale van de romancyclus zit hem niet in deze pregnante traumatiek, maar in de manier waarop St Aubyn daar vorm aan geeft. Intrigerend is bijvoorbeeld dat het verhaal niet puur vanuit het perspectief van Patrick wordt verteld, maar door een van buitenaf observerende anonieme verteller die meerdere personages van binnenuit volgt. Die verteller oordeelt niet, maar parafraseert zonder commentaar wat die personages denken. Gevolg is dat deze complexe tragedie vanuit veel verschillende perspectieven bekeken wordt, wat een rijker beeld oplevert dan alleen maar het perspectief van Patrick. Al vrij snel wordt b.v. ook verteld hoe Patricks moeder Eleanor vertwijfeld mijmert over hoe ze toch met de even tragische als vreselijke David is getrouwd. En dat leidt tot echt briljante zinnen als: " When she had first met David twelve years ago, she had been fascinated by his looks. The expression that men feel entitled to wear when they stare out of a cold English drawing room onto their own land had grown stubborn over five centuries and perfected itself in David's face". Om die laatste zin moet ik dan hard lachen: prachtig werkelijk hoe in een paar woorden de volstrekt op niets gebaseerde arrogantie van David wordt bespot, en hoe ook de aristocratische klasse waaruit hij afkomstig is te kijk wordt gezet. Maar even prachtig is hoe tegelijk de schrijnende teleurstelling van Eleanor voelbaar wordt in precies diezelfde zin: hoe die "cold English drawing room" voor haar ook de kilte oproept in David's innerlijk. En zelfs nog wat genialer vind ik hoe deze zinnen ook een sfeer van verstarring oproepen, en daarmee al een beeld geven van de tragiek van David: iemand die verstard is in zijn sociale mislukking en zijn valse zelfbeeld van Angelsaksische snob, iemand ook die juist vanwege die verstarring een tiran is die zijn vrouw en kind traumatiseert. En naarmate de romancyclus vordert wint deze zin ook nog aan rijkdom, omdat je meer en meer kanten ziet van de fnuikende teleurstellingen van Davids leven maar ook meer en meer kanten van zijn stuitende monsterachtigheid.Het ongelofelijke van deze romancyclus nu is dat er op elke bladzij wel een paar van dit soort zinnen staan. Zinnen die mij hardop laten lachen, omdat ze zo aanstekelijk satirisch zijn, terwijl ze tegelijk ook op erg rake wijze de tragiek voelbaar maken van de verschillende personages. Of ook hun woede en teleurstelling, vooral in de passages waarin Patrick wordt gevolgd. Zo heeft Patrick, tijdens een treurige en gefrustreerde mijmering n.a.v. de begrafenis van zijn moeder, de volgende gedachte:"Everything needed to embalm a Christian. Eleanor had expected to meet Jesus at the end of the tunnel after she died. The poor man was a slave of his fans, waiting to show crowds of eager dead the neon countryside that lay bevond the rebirth canal of earthly annihilation. It must be hard to be chosen as optimism's master cliché, the Light at the end of the Tunnel, ruling over a glittering army of half- full glasses and silver-lined clouds". Ook weer een bewonderenswaardig komische zin naar mijn smaak, met een echt jaloersmakend trefzekere woordkeus. Zelden zal kwezelachtig Christendom zo vlijmscherp zijn bespot in zulke rake bewoordingen. Maar tegelijk is dit ook een zin die de bittere spot en daarmee de wanhoop van Patrick prachtig voelbaar maakt: de machteloze woede richting zijn gestorven moeder, en daarnaast ook zijn eigen totale ongeloof in verlossingen zoals het Christendom die belooft. En dat laatste is weer tragisch, omdat hij enorm vast zit in zijn eigen hoofd en dat zelf ook weet, en geen uitweg ziet uit deze impasse.Ruim 800 bladzijden sleept St Aubyn ons dus mee met dit soort geweldige zinnen, die steeds nieuwe intrigerende perspectieven werpen op de dilemma's waar m.n. Patrick mee worstelt. Daar zitten echt enorm enerverende stukken tussen over de totaal verslaafde Patrick en zijn highs en lows als junk, maar ook geweldige ironische gesprekken van David en zijn beste vriend die ondanks alle - vaak briljante en dolkomische- ironische omwegen of gênante stiltes TOCH heel trefzeker zijn. In 'Some Hope', het grappigste en meest satirische deel, wordt een werkelijk gitzwart sarcastische blik geworpen op de perfiditeit van sommige Engelse aristocraten (de wereld dus waarin de wortels liggen van Patrcks vader): om je gek te lachen zo hilarisch en vilein, maar tegelijk ook volkomen claustrofobisch en huiveringwekkend. En in 'Mother's Milk', mijns inziens het mooiste deel, staan echt ongehoord prachtige stukken over de pre-verbale belevingswereld van Patricks kinderen: een belevingswereld die nog niet de taal en conventies van de volwassenen volgt, nu dus nog vrij is daarvan, en dus erg verlokkend voor Patrick. Want Patrick begint meer en meer te beseffen dat het wezenlijke juist aan taal ontsnapt, en dat zijn eigen vaak briljante ironie en taalvaardigheid ook een blokkade opwerpt in zijn eigen hoofd. En ook dat zijn eigen neiging tot sarcasme een bepaalde vrijheid blokkeert: de vrijheid om zijn ouders niet eenduidig te veroordelen, hoe verleidelijk dat ook is, maar om hun karakters vanuit meerdere perspectieven te bezien en om te accepteren dat ook zijn eigen leven vol open vragen zit die je niet met dichtsmeren met een sarcastisch antwoord. Want alleen de vraag houdt de vrije reflectie open.Het was werkelijk een enorm genot om 800 bladzijden lang zulk geniaal en elegant proza te mogen lezen over zulke traumatische levens. En zoals Edmund White in een recensie schreef: " So much good writing is in itself a form of Health". Als je in zulk scherpzinnig en vaak hilarisch proza kunt schrijven over zulke trauma's , dan heb je al een aardig begin gemaakt met het overwinnen van die trauma's. Natuurlijk is Patrick vaak ook een gevangene van zijn eigen intelligentie en zet hij zichzelf helemaal vast met de scherpzinnige draaikolken in zijn altijd maar analyserende en observerende hoofd. Maar diezelfde intelligentie en taalvaardigheid geeft, zo blijkt op de laatste ontroerende bladzijden van deze cyclus, ook inzicht en een glimp van hoop. Of liever, een begin van een nieuwe denkroute: niet een denkroute die naar verlossing of een definitieve troost zoekt, maar naar een manier om de ongetroostheid te accepteren. En die acceptatie geeft dan ook een nieuwe, onvermoede vrijheid.Dat laatste levert in mijn handen meteen een kitschzin op, zoals jullie zien, maar St Aubyn formuleert ook dit aarzelende inzicht geweldig. Zoals hij alles geweldig formuleert. Ik zou zeggen: koop die cyclus, lees alles achter elkaar met volledige overgave en onderdompeling, proef al zijn briljante zinnen op je tong, en geniet!

Whoa and wow. I really enjoyed this - and having all five books collected together is probably what made this a 5-star experience. The writing is fantastic - St Aubyn can put words together so well (the only downside to reading with my ears is that I have ZERO examples to share). And I really came to care about - and love - the cast of characters. Even Patrick (but not his father, I'm still undecided about his mother and Robert might be my favorite). I decided to read the books when I read that Benedict Cumberbatch is going to play Patrick in a Showtime adaptation. Must admit, I think BC is going to be wonderful as Patrick (and I totally enjoyed picturing him as Patrick). I can only hope the TV show does justice to St Aubyn's style.

“He sometimes had to remind himself that he wasn't an infant any more, to argue that there were real children in the house, not yet horror-trained; he sometimes had to give himself a good talking-to. Nevertheless, he waited in vain for the maturing effects of parenthood. Being surrounded by children only brought him closer to his own childishness. He felt like a man who dreads leaving harbour, knowing that under the deck of his impressive yacht there is only a dirty little twin-stroke engine: fearing and wanting, fearing and wanting.”I read this quintet of novels on holiday – about 900 pages in all. I staggered the read – interspersing each book with something quite different because I got a bit sick of the Melrose family. They are not nice people. But there’s a certain addictive element. (Ironically as many of the characters suffer from horrendous addictions.) I’d wanted to read it for a while after hearing Edward St Aubyn interviewed on Radio National. (Warning – plot spoilers ahead)It’s hardly interesting to write about these books without acknowledging that they have a strong autobiographical element. St Aubyn’s family is a well-connected old English family. “The St Aubyn family have pedigree. The first St Aubyn baronetcy was created in 1671; St Michael’s Mount in Cornwall is the family seat. Teddy, as Edward is known to his friends, is godfather to one of Earl Spencer’s children. His father, Roger, was an Old Etonian, a lieutenant in the Hussars, a surgeon and frustrated musician. His mother, Lorna, was descended from an American family whose considerable fortune could be traced back to her great-grandfather’s candle and lard-oil business in Cincinnati.” (http://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/bo...) “I have spent 22 years trying to transform painful experience into pleasurable reading,” St Aubyn says. The narrative of the first book Never Mind opens with a horrific sexual assault by the father, David, on his five year old son Patrick. St Aubyn later told people that this had been what happened to him as a young boy; it wasn’t until he was eight that he persuaded his father to stop the assaults. The novels follow the life of Patrick as he grows into a dysfunctional adult ““What would it be like to live without consolation, or the desire for consolation?” — and realizes, He would never find out, unless he uprooted the consolatory system that had started on the hillside at Saint-Nazaire and then spread to every medicine cabinet, bed and bottle he had come across since; substitutes substituting for substitutes: the system was always more fundamental than its contents, and the mental act more fundamental still.” Events play out against the backdrop of well-heeled society in the south of France, at an English country party, in the 5 star hotels of New Yprk. There is money but the family fortunes are in decline so Patrick, along with managing his various addictions, must manage to be the first of six generations to think about earning a living.The books are chocka with quotable lines. He is a very funny, ascerbic writer. Here’s some examples. “As a guest, Emily Price had three main drawbacks: she was incapable of saying please, incapable of saying thank you, and incapable of saying sorry, all the while creating a surge in the demand for these expressions.”And““It was late May, it was hot, and he really ought to take off his overcoat, but his overcoat was his defense against the thin shards of glass that passers-¬by slipped casually under his skin, not to mention the slow-motion explosion of shop windows, the bone-rattling thunder of subway trains and the heartbreaking passage of each second, like a grain of sand trickling through the hourglass of his body. No, he would not take off his overcoat. Do you ask a lobster to disrobe?”And “…it was easy enough to see that her slightly protruding blue eyes were blank screens of self-love on which a small selection of fake emotions was allowed to flicker. She made rather haphazard impersonations of someone who has relationships with others.”The books tend to be short and intense, often focussing on a few days at most. There is a brittleness about them that reflects the characters. The writing is clever but self-conscious. I think that just as the characters can’t quite allow themselves to really feel the impact of the horrible behaviour of friends and family, this also plays out for the reader. The clever irony creates a distance so we read with wryness rather than connection. One reviewer describes the fiction as “a shriek of filial hatred; most of the posh English who people his novels are virulently repellent. The snobs, drunkards, pedophiles, fools, tyrants, and addicts who pass through these pages are garishly demonic, in a way that seems at once contemporary and oddly timeless.” (http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/201...) I thought of Nancy Mitford while I was reading, there is a kindness in her writing that is lacking here. But maybe St Aubyn has nothing to be kind about. In one interview he says: ‘We used to have a new nanny or au pair every three weeks because none of them could stand the atmosphere in the house,’ he says. ‘One of them, a brave French woman, stayed a little bit longer than the rest. When I published Never Mind in France she wrote me a letter saying, “I’ve felt guilty all my life, because I used to hear you down the corridor screaming and I knew it was much, much worse than an ordinary punishment, but I was only 19 and I was so frightened of your father…”” (http://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/bo...)
BELATED REVIEW:Really one of the great novel series; so acidic, concentrated, empathetic; not a word out of place.

‘Het toekennen van menselijke waarden aan de natuur, projectie, substitutie en repressie, het maakte allemaal deel uit van het onvermijdelijke verkeer tussen willekeurig welke geest en de omgeving waarin hij verkeerde, maar door de pathologische intensiteit die hij in dit mechanisme had gelegd, was het voor hem van wezenlijk belang om het te doorgronden. Hoe zou het zijn te moeten leven zonder vertroosting, of het verlangen naar vertroosting? Daar zou hij nooit achter komen, tenzij hij erin slaagde het vertroostingsmechanisme onklaar te maken dat in gang was gezet op die helling in Saint-Nazaire en dat zich vervolgens had uitgebreid naar alle denkbare medicijnkastjes, bedden en flessen die op zijn pad waren gekomen; substituten van substituten van substituten: het systeem was altijd veel fundamenteler dan de elementen, en het functioneren van de geest nog weer veel fundamenteler. Stel dat herinneringen niet veel meer waren dan herinneringen, zonder enig vermogen om te troosten of te kwellen? Zouden ze dan überhaupt bestaan, of was het altijd een emotionele druk die beelden ontlokte aan wat mogelijk niet meer was dan alle verzamelde ervaringen? Zelfs wanneer dat het geval was, moesten er toch betere bibliothecarissen zijn om te zoeken in de schemerige en overvolle rekken dan paniek, rancune en verscheurende weemoed.’Tuig van de richel, dat is die upper class, gevuld met ledigheid en zelfvernietiging. Edward St Aubyn beschrijft ze ‘van binnen uit’, met vileine pen en briljante ironie, en laat er geen spaander van heel. Maar zo veel schrijnender is zijn eigen verhaal daarin. En toch is het scalpel dat hij hanteert vlijmscherp. Hij gaat tot op het bod en vaker nog diep erin tot de inktzwarte etter van een beschadigd leven vrije loop krijgt. Zoveel wanhoop, dat een mens dat ooit te boven komt is haast ondenkbaar. Pas wanneer Patrick ophoudt troost te zoeken, kan hij de opgelopen trauma’s loslaten. Na 840 bladzijden schitterend proza.

I select books to read in a lot of different ways. Sometimes, I read a review that intrigues me; other times, from a friend's recommendation; occasionally, it's for the simply expedient reason that the book was on sale and looked interesting. I have no idea why I selected this book. Even after going back to read reviews, some of which were complimentary. This is actually a compilation of 5 shorter books, and if you have 27 hours of your life you care nothing about, devote them to the audio rendition of this book. Only, however, if you enjoy tedious, narcissistic expositions on child abuse and its long term implications on a person's life, drug abuse in unnecessarily graphic and boring description, and one book devoted entirely to what is surely the longest funeral in the history of the literary world. Perhaps there are others who will be enlightened by the tedium of this droning book, if there are, I'm not sure they would be people I would enjoy socializing with. So, no, didn't care for it.

Alle Patrick Melrose romans in een band. Het eerste boek verscheen al in 1992, de andere boeken in 1994, 2006, 2011 en 2014.Ik ben omver geblazen. Zo Scherp. Bladzijde na bladzijde vol met gedenkwaardige vlijmscherpe zinnen. Genieten. De schrijver zoomt per boek genadeloos in op verschillende periodes in Patrick Melroses leven. Ondanks alle getroebleerd toestanden is alles zo helder en knap met vileine humor beschreven. Een genot om te lezen.

Okay. I'll try my best to deduce this five-part tale of privilege, aristocracy, and debauchery. Patrick Melrose features as our primary character, but the stories are of his world: the abuse, fall from grace, grapples with money and lineage, attempts at redemption. It is a story of the collapse of the moneyed class, mostly due to their own hubris, but also because of changes they are unwilling to accept. Ugliness ensues when clinging to a life that's passed us by.Never Mind: The first book in the series. Patrick is a young child who undergoes horrific abuse -physically, psychologically, verbal - from his father. This novel centers primarily on the broken but still-intact family that will lay the groundwork for Patrick's future self. While part of the narrative focuses on Patrick's misunderstood and fragile upbringing, much of Never Mind introduces readers to his family, their friends, their customs, their pettiness. The Provance locale, the novel's setting (and later a fiercely-contested piece of the family's inheritance), acts as a paradox, a deformed homage to the family's wealth and status that is both prison and vacation home. The father is particularly cruel in dealing with Patrick, Patrick's mother Eleanor, any friends or family visiting, housemaids or other hired help, and animals. He is a beastly character, a sinister creation in the best tradition of English literature. Sad that he's based on a real man.Bad News: My favorite in the series. Patrick is now in his early 20s and hopelessly addicted to heroin. He receives news that his father has died, and he must fly to New York to collect the ashes. The novel encompasses his fraught and disastrous weekend as he balances the fallout of his father's death with his obsessive need to buy and consume his drugs. The detail to which St. Aubyn chronicles Patrick's drug abuse is uncomfortable, but equally fascinating. It's a fast-paced narrative compared to the extended interior monologues of the other books. St. Aubyn use his omniscience to great effect starting with Bad News. Although we follow Patrick through his ghastly trials, we also shift perspective and begin to see Patrick through the eyes of others: his friends, an old girlfriend, his father's acquaintances at the funeral parlor. Patrick is not some destroyed hero coping with his savage upbringing through drug addition; he's a spoiled brat with too much money and time who feels the world owes him something. The shift in narrative storytelling, I believe, is a technique used so that we are unable to sympathize or romanticize Patrick. A masterful piece of writing, in my opinion.Some Hope: I think this is the shortest in the series, and as I was reading it I found it to be my least favorite. However, I kept thinking about it, and it's really incredibly funny. St. Aubyn takes a lighter tone with this novel. Patrick is in recovery and attends some fancy, aristocratic party that he desperately does not want to go to. The narrative moves away from Patrick and centers on different partygoers, their petty grievances and thinly-veiled snobbery. The acerbic brand of humor is very British. Much of it upon initial reading I breezed right by. The most satirical novel of the five.Mother's Milk: The award-winning novel of the series. Very good, very insightful. Patrick has recovered from his heroin addiction and seemingly has his life together. He is married, a barrister, the father of two young children. The novel begins, interestingly, from the perspective of his newborn son. We see obvious differences in young Thomas' life when compared to Patrick's in the first novel, but the sordid legacies of money (never enough of it) abuse (more self-inflicted at this point) and distraction (child-rearing instead of drugs) still linger. The central conflict in Patrick's life, sadly, is boredom. He has no real marriage because his wife, Mary, concerns herself only with the children; his dying mother has bequeathed their French property to some shamanistic quack that Patrick is determined to fight; he longs for alcohol and pills as forms of self-medication to combat the sad normality of his life. The pull of aristocracy, their former life of grandeur, weighs heavily on Patrick, and he is determined to rescue some of it, kicking and screaming, no matter how sad and pathetic he comes off. It is an exercise in self-sabotage, the only thing at which Patrick seems to excel. Mother's Milk is the most impressive piece of writing in the series. The narrative transitions effortlessly between dialogue - both heated and conversational - and interior monologue (of all age ranges and perspectives), all the while pushing the story to its conclusion.At Last: The final novel spans in present time only a couple of hours, the funeral and wake for Patrick's mother. Patrick is divorced, has lost the family vacation property, has recently come through rehab for alcoholism. One would think he is a broken man at wit's end, but At Last is the most hopeful novel of the series. It seems as if Patrick has finally been able to shed the terrible burden of expectation, the inherited curse of his life over which he has fumbled and suffered and royally screwed-up every meaningful relationship he has ever had. He's still the snarky, pessimistic Patrick of old (one can never change too much), but the series ends with Patrick thinking of the future without the usual despair. It's small consolation - we can't ever (and aren't supposed to) feel bad for Patrick necessarily - but we witness a man who has been through the ringer (put himself through it as well) and has come through to the other side with renewed hope in his existence, his life moving forward with his own broken family. The series ends in Patrick's head, that tempestuous and fragile place. We can only hope that it doesn't consume him further, that he can learn, maybe, not to be happy, but to be content.The Patrick Melrose novels are a labor of love that require patience and a willingness to look past the cloak of inherited wealth to find the human suffering beneath.

St Aubyn's narrative cycle of pain, based upon his own life as an aristo spawn in modern Britain and environs (France, New York), provides much beauty even as the flawless prose digs deep into the vile psychology and behaviors of the landed gentry. I raced to finish before the televised version starring Benedict Cumberbatch (a satirical name worthy of the book), and the combined experience has been deeply disturbing and infinitely enjoyable. Young Patrick is raped by his father and ignored by his mother, leading to a life of addiction and self-hate. The five novels depict the origin story and then follow this messed up guy as he stumbles towards healing, all along the way hurting himself and many others, determined to show up for his two kids. Oddly hopeful, viciously satirical, endlessly entertaining.
Brilliant. Gorgeous. Tragic. Exhilarating. Five of the best books I've ever read.

I read the first 4 books of the 5-novel audiobook - including Never Mind, Bad News, Some Hope, and Mother's Milk. Taking a mental health break from Patrick Melrose and will return to finish the final novel -At Last.

De Patrick Melrose romans zijn vijf boeken die apart zijn geschreven en gepubliceerd, maar ook gebundeld zijn uitgegeven. De bundel leest als een integrale roman over het leven van Patrick Melrose met vijf delen. StAubyn bespreekt loodzware thema's met een lichte en ironische stijl.Vooral de eerste twee boeken zijn een voorbeeld van de tovenarij van kunst: alleen kunst kan uit een afzichtelijke en wrede werkelijkheid schoonheid scheppen waar je van een afstand met bewondering naar wilt kijken, zoals je soms naar een mooi mens wilt kijken zonder enige intentie om onderdeel te worden van het leven van die persoon. Boek één: Laat maar (1992)'Laat maar' beschrijft de jeugd van Patrick in een disfunctioneel elitair Engels gezin. Vader David is verarmde oude Noord-Engelse landadel en getrouwd met de Amerikaanse Eleanor voor haar geld en omdat hij haar kon domineren. Beide doen niets, hun leven bestaat uit decadentie en ledigheid. Ooit was David een getalenteerd pianist, totdat reuma daar een eind aan maakte. David heeft geneeskunde gestudeerd, tegen de wil in van zijn militaire vader die dat maar voor het plebs vond en David om die reden heeft onterfd; David heeft het vak nooit echt uitgeoefend. David speelt Bach (de strenge glorie van het oude Europa), Eleanor luistert naar Porgy en Bess (de jazzy stijl van de nieuwe wereld Amerika): "I got plenty of nothing, and nothing's plenty for me."; in de opera van Gershwin is dat tekst voor zwarte slaven die niets hebben behalve elkaars liefde; in dit boek is het andersom: deze mensen zijn slaaf van hun geld, bezit, elkaar en sociale status, maar ontberen liefde. Van lieverlee, of uit verveling en zelfverachting, misbruikt de sadistische David zowel zijn vrouw als zijn kind psychologisch en fysiek: Eleanor is verslaafd aan alcohol en medicijnen en Patrick al op vijfjarige leeftijd het slachtoffer van psychische mishandeling, geweld en verkrachting. To top it all off is Patrick ook zelf het resultaat van een verkrachting.'Laat maar' beschrijft maar één dag uit het leven van deze liederlijke personages en nog wat meelijwekkende figuren uit hun entourage. Een dag is voor StAubyn voldoende om deze mensen te portretteren in een mooie ironische stijl. Zelfs de dingen uiten zich als verval: "De gordijnen bolden op en zakten weer in, als verzwakte longen." Het is een mooi en rijk boek over lelijke mensen in alle opzichten, op de vijfjarige Patrick na, met wie je alleen maar medelijden kunt hebben. Kleine zinnen hebben grote betekenis, zoals deze: "De bekoring van open horizonten verloor onmiskenbaar iets van haar charme als je bagage bij je had." Letterlijk te lezen, maar ook als filosofische kanttekening.Quotes"Het was Eleanor nooit helemaal duidelijk geworden waarom Engelsen meenden zich erop te kunnen laten voorstaan dat ze vele generaties op een en dezelfde plek geen steek hadden uitgevoerd, maar het was zonneklaar dat David zich geheel in deze opvatting kon vinden.""Waar men naar streeft, zei David, is ennui. (...) Het is saaiheid plus geld, of saaiheid plus arrogantie. Ik vind alles maar saai dus ik ben interessant - dat idee."Boek twee: Slecht nieuws (1992)Patrick is 22 als hij te horen krijgt dat zijn gehate vader David is overleden. Hij reist naar New York om zijn vaders as op te halen. Je leest gelijk op de eerste pagina's dat Patrick heroïne gebruikt. Slecht nieuws is het leven van de verslaafde Patrick Melrose samengebald in een waanzinnige, egocentrische en destructieve trip van drie dagen en nachten.Net als in boek één ook hier een mooie soepele en ironische stijl, soms ronduit grappig. Knappe, venijnige en afschuwwekkende beschrijvingen van hoe het voelt om onder invloed van alcohol en drugs te zijn. En hoe dwangmatig verslaving is, met haar wanen, hallucinaties en angsten zoals paranoia en stemmen. Mooie beeldspraken, zoals deze: "Naar beneden in de trage, bedompte lift, langs de achterlijke, dikke conciërge, de straat op. De schok om opnieuw onder die fletse, weidsere hemel te staan, zonder enige bescherming. Zo moest de oester zich voelen als het citroensap naar beneden drupt."Quotes"Alleen achter een waterval van meedogenloze en aangename sensaties (...) kon hij zich verschuilen voor de bloedhonden van zijn bewustzijn." "Patrick wierp een blik op de straat. Het was net de openingsscène van een documentaire over overbevolking.""Zodra hij heroïne had genomen kon hij zich heel goed voorstellen dat hij zonder zou kunnen; als hij zonder zat kon hij alleen maar voorstellen dat hij meer wilde.""Mensen denken dat ze individuen zijn omdat ze het woord 'ik' zo vaak gebruiken.""Was er dan nergens rust, nergens een plek om op adem te komen? Natuurlijk niet. Wat een bespottelijke vraag."Boek drie: Wat heet hoop (1994)Boek drie springt 8 jaar vooruit in de tijd vanaf boek twee. Patrick heeft drug ingeruild voor casual sex: "(...) de bescheiden rush van een orgasme, zoveel vluchtiger en bewerkelijker dan de rush van drugs (...)". Patrick heeft moeite met de realiteit, vind alle 'gewone mensen' afschuwelijk en huichelachtig. Het boek beschrijft de slappe wereld van praatgroepen van ex-drugsgebruikers, en de liefdeloze wereld van de Engelse adel en aanverwante happy few. Beide werelden zijn op een vreemde manier verwant: iedereen denkt alleen maar aan zichzelf, huichelachtigheid heerst en beide hebben een heel eigen jargon. Bij de snobs zijn de mannen alleen maar bezig in een vrouw in hun bed te krijgen, telkens een andere dan waarmee ze getrouwd zijn; die vrouwen op hun beurt zijn alleen maar uit op toegang tot en opklimmen in de upper class. Eén daarvan beklaagt zich dat ze nog nooit zoiets ordinairs als het Grote Barrièrerif heeft gezien: "(...) één grote nachtmerrie vol felle, schreeuwerige kleuren, een warboel van groenblauw en krankzinnige tinten oranje, waarbij ook nog eens je duikbril voortdurend vol water loopt." Hahaha. Vlak voor één van de decadente feesten biecht Patrick het seksuele misbruik uit zijn jeugd op aan een vriend, een net als hijzelf cleane junk. Deze gebeurtenis blijkt wat los te maken in hem. Op het feest krijgt Patrick het inzicht dat hij naast de haat die hij voelt voor zijn vader (de agressor) en zijn moeder (de passieve die het toeliet) ook begrip zou kunnen hebben voor hun verziekte geesten en hun diepe ongeluk; het inzicht dat die twee zaken naast elkaar kunnen bestaan, geeft Patrick hoop (de hoop uit de titel?). De prinses, zus van de koningin, die op hetzelfde feest is, portretteert StAubyn genadeloos als een arrogante wereldvreemde snob. Patrick krijgt van een oude bekende van zijn ouders te horen dat hij zich schuldig maakt aan de grootste zonde van allemaal: "Je tijd uitzitten." Het boek eindigt als Patrick aan het eind van het feest buiten staat en zich gewaar wordt van de 'gewone' natuur: zwanen, meeuwen, een meertje, sneeuw. Het geeft hem een goed gevoel; er gloort hoop voor Patrick.Boek vier: Moedermelk (2006)'Moedermelk' opent met de geboorte van het tweede kind van Patrick, geschreven vanuit het perspectief van die baby en zijn 5-jarige zoon. Dat komt wat geforceerd over, omdat StAubyn de kinderen heel volwassen taal en gedachten in de mond legt. Dat blijft zo in dit boek, een minpuntje. Patrick is 42, werkt als jurist. Het is 20 jaar na het drugsfiësta uit boek twee. Hij lijkt 'gewoon' te zijn geworden. Veel aandacht voor de 'gewone' problemen van ouders met jonge kinderen: het zorgen, slaapgebrek, niet meer aan zichzelf en elkaar toekomen, geen libido meer, aftakelende ouders...Patricks moeder takelt af en heeft Patrick onterfd door het huis in Frankrijk aan een new age stichting te schenken. Haar verraad is totaal als ze daarna van Patrick hulp bij zelfdoding verlangt. Patrick neemt zich voor om de keten van het doorgeven van ellende aan je kinderen te doorbreken.Patrick slikt Tamazepam tegen zijn angsten. Hij verlangt naar de vergetelheid van zijn oude drugsverslaving en slaat aan het drinken. "Ik heb geen hout meer voor het vuur dat de wilde dieren op afstand moet houden, dat idee. Maar ook iets wat veel verwarrender is - de wilde dieren zijn een deel van mezelf, dat aan de winnende hand is. Ik kan alleen voorkomen dat ze mij doden door hen te doden, maar ik kan hen niet doden zonder ook mezelf te doden." In een poging om de depressie af te leiden, gaat Patrick vreemd met jeugdliefde Julia. Hij rechtvaardigt dat als een gunst aan zijn vrouw, die hem niet de tederheid meer biedt waarnaar hij verlangt: "Bij ons zit het in de familie, dat filantropische trekje." Hahaha. "Het was allemaal voorbij, het huwelijk had helemaal niets te bieden, alleen verplichtingen en verantwoordelijkheden." De stijl van boek vier is minder ironisch dan de eerste twee. Op momenten even intens als de eerste twee delen, vooral als Patrick wegzakt in zijn depressie en drankzucht.Boek vijf: Eindelijk (2011)Boek vijf beschrijft dat dag van Patricks' moeders uitvaart. We leren over haar familie en de onterving door haar moeder. Patrick leeft gescheiden van zijn gezin en heeft zich laten opnemen voor depressie. De uitvaart is één groot huichelachtig festijn van alle hoofdpersonen uit haar leven. Patrick laat (eindelijk?) de gedachte toe dat hij vroeger speelbal is geweest in de sadomasochistische verhouding van zijn ouders. Dat zijn moeder hem niet had beschermd, omdat ze behoefte had gehad aan de vernedering en Patrick daar onderdeel van had gemaakt. Als op de uitvaart ook de oude vriend van zijn ouders Nicholas Pratt overlijdt, is Patrick voldoende bevrijd van zijn verleden om de draad van zijn leven op te pakken. Hij grijpt niet naar drank, drugs of sex maar wil naar zijn kinderen en belt zijn vrouw...

Leaning toward 4.5 stars. This was a bit difficult to get through at first, not so much because of the subject matter (which was horrifying and traumatic, but tempered with that amazing dry British humor), but because of the language. It was beautifully written, but... man, it's not something you breeze through easily. It was clearly written by and about the British upper class, and I'd often forget it took place in the twentieth and twenty-first century, because the vocabulary and tone was so similar to classic British novels from hundreds of years ago.St. Aubyn's prose reminds me of Ian McEwan, in that he delves into the very depths of his protagonist's mind (as well of the minds of other characters in other sections of the book). Understandable, since this is heavily based on the author's own life, but the level of insight is still incredible. The streams of consciousness were often dreamlike, flowing easily from one subject to the next, with slight interjections of opinions and observations. You learn how each character thinks. It's amazing.I was extremely attached to Patrick, despite all his bad behavior. He is the central character of each book, and you just want him to be happy and healthy. We see him grow from an abused, helpless little boy to a lost young man self-destructing with drugs, to a lost adult (temporarily) sober and adrift, to a(n unfaithful) husband and father terrified of repeating the mistakes of his family's past, all the while craving the love of his parents while simultaneously resenting them for their abuse and neglect.I also found myself laughing at odd moments in the book, which I believe is a coping mechanism the author uses for himself and for the audience because of the dark subject matter. How do you laugh at a story that's based on the worst kind of childhood abuse? But St. Aubyn makes it possible, without the reader feeling awful for doing so.I stayed up late last night to finish the book, and I was so relieved to feel the catharsis of the ending, right along with Patrick. It's definitely a bleak series, but the ending is hopeful. For all the terrible things that happen throughout the books, and for all the demons Patrick fights, I considered this ending to be happy, and when I finally closed the book after finishing, I fell asleep relieved and lighter.I highly recommend this book, but warn against the subject matter. It is beautifully, poetically written as it deals with childhood sexual abuse and childhood physical abuse, parental alcoholism and neglect, suicide, and heavy drug usage.With a dash of dry British humor to soften the blow.

Five novels : Never Mind, Bad News, Some Hope, Mother's Milk, and At Last'At Last' is about how I felt upon finishing over 850 pages of the pained, sardonic and deeply self-aware interior dialogue of Patrick Melrose."Fucking hell, thought Patrick, what do these people do all day, write scripts for The Brady Bunch? He hated happy families with their mutual encouragement, and their demonstrative affection, and the impression they gave of valuing each other more than other people. It was utterly disgusting."Just when you want to abandon these upper-crust Brits in their refined London, Provence, and New York milieus, you get drawn back in by the clever, sort of odious dialog. It reads a bit like Moliere."There are so many varieties of snobbism...one cannot admire all of them." "Snobbery is one of the things one should be most discriminating about."The chapters where Patrick is in the grips of full-blown, multiple addictions are graphic, in a dispassionate way, and grueling to read. More enjoyable is St. Aubyn's ability to write from the point of view of very young children; in this case of Patrick and then his two sons. He makes you remember how deeply and intuitively children can think. "Sometimes he imagined he was the thing he was looking at, sometimes he imagined he was in the space in between, but the best was when he was just looking, without being anyone in particular or looking at anything in particular, and then he floated in the looking, like the breeze blowing without needing cheeks to blow or having anywhere particular to go."The characters are well realized and become familiar as you progress in the books, and you can even develop affection for some (Patrick's wife and boys). The novels could be mined for several seasons' worth of a disturbed comedy about people without occupation, yet with considerable property."What I find with beautiful women... is that, after one's waited around for ages, they all arrive at once, as buses are supposed to do. Not that I've ever waited around for a bus, except at that British Heritage thing in Washington. Do you remember?""Yes, of course... They hired a double-decker bus for us.""Some people said 'coals to Newcastle', but I was jolly pleased to see what I'd been missing all these years."Princess Margaret, wearing a blue tulle dress, appears in a funny cameo at a dinner party.Really good books, but quite an undertaking to read the whole cycle at once.

This book was such a rollercoaster. I think some people might find this to be a grand story, but I guess it wasn't my type of story (even though I really thought it would be). The whole second book the main character (and others) was only bitterly brooding and taking drugs, which just made me angry. The third book was only about people from the upper class getting ready for a big party. Perhaps I didn't relate to or connect with the characters, which is why the text fell flat for me. As to the text - there was sometimes a bit too much of it. Maybe the whole point of the book was to show the brutality of life, I don't know (I know the story is to a great extent self-biographical, which makes me feel bad for criticizing it). However, I must admit the dialogue was very witty and there were quite a few passages I really enjoyed, those kind of sentences when you need to stop reading and appreciate them for a while. I really did love those. After battling through the first three books I reach the 4th one and suddenly I love it! It's as if there has been an awakening, either within me or the author. The 5th was just as wonderful, there was a mature depth and truth in it (not to sound too pretentious...), and the ending couldn't have been better!!! How come there was such a dfference between the five novels? Perhaps it was a way for the writer to show life's evolution, what do I know. To conclude, there is no doubt that St Aubyn is a great writer, I just believe this book had to reach the right hands to be justly appreciated, and perhaps mine weren't entirely so, just to a certain extent. It was, however, a great read.

A sharp, gut-wrenching story of addiction and recovery set in a wry comedy of manners. The extraordinary prose and the uniquely genuine journey of survival of the tortured and fascinating protagonist is weighed down by endless discussions of soulless fools who merit no attention. A strange and livid modern fable, darker and more honest than Nancy Mitford to whom this has been compared as a commentary on the British upper class. I was, again, weighed down by the experience that the unflinching insight of the words yet were not quite honed enough to pierce the bell jar of human evil in the story. The wit is gorgeous. But the fact that persevering against the wearying treadmill of human greed, self-delusion, and vileness ends in few victories is a harrowing truth. The mirror to the human condition reflects such tragedy and horror and tediousness and courage. The brief candles of hope do hold forth, for a rare few moments, in an all too true portrayal of reality. There are no sentimental or inspirational illusions here. I am afraid the non-ending left me hanging, like a dry wake for a drunk. Maybe that was part of the point, that the story isn't over. I would certainly read another installment if it were written. This book demanded quite an emotional investment from me, and it was worth it. I recommend it if you love brilliant sarcasm and aren't overwhelmed by the brutality of the negative portrait of our fellow humans. Astonishingly candid and brave, at times laugh out loud hilarious, skeweringly witty, but very sad. Makes me appreciate the strange way in which the limitations of poverty have some genuine lessons for a person. Also makes one appreciate, for all of its banality, and hypocrisy of practice, the general value placed on wholesomeness in the Middle class. Interesting, fascinating, and cautionary. Heartbreaking and yet, very insightful and in places, very very darkly funny.

A melhor literatura é a que deriva da experiência pessoal do autor, ganha com algum acréscimo da imaginação e é revestida pelo talento literário.Os cinco livros que compõem as Novelas Completas são exatamente isso: a rara (e crudelíssima) experiência do autor, intermediada por uma imaginação refinada pela literatura e empacotada com o melhor estilo possível. O amargo humor inglês, que em alguns passos lembra o Evelyn W. (de "A Handful of Dust", por exemplo), é mais um bônus.Diz o autor, numa entrevista do youtube (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=blMi_...) que quando ele esteve isolado, pelos 25 primeiros anos da vida dele, em que ele não contou a verdade sobre sua infância a ninguém, foi a literatura que o alcançou, foi com ela que ele se sentiu ligado a outra inteligência, a outra imaginação.Mas não é esse o fim mesmo da literatura? Transmitir a experiência humana, alcançar-nos quando estamos distantes, mostrar-nos que, afinal, não somos os únicos com os nossos problemas?E o autor, aqui, foi mais adiante: usou toda a literatura como terapia (que, a rigor, salvou-lhe a vida) e, aliando-a à sua experiência pessoal, produziu uma rara obra-prima, daquelas que nos devolvem docemente à nossa pequenez e à nossa ignorância fundamental.

I think the best characterization of Patrick Melrose is actually from Giovanni's Room, by James Baldwin:  ...the usual, knife-blade lean, tight-trousered boys. One could never be sure...whether they were after money or blood or love. They moved about the bar incessantly, cadging cigarettes and drinks, with something behind their eyes at once terrible vulnerable and terrible hard. These novels are: extremely British, intellectual, and depressing (maybe I should have just said extremely British). Its main character is pretty much the most Byronic hero you could ever hope for. He mopes, he cracks up, he suffers. But it's well done, and realistic, and in all my annoyance with Patrick's "stylized despair" (as Edward St. Aubyn himself puts it), I could not help loving him. My favorite novel out of the collection is Bad News. It features a dialogue between several hallucinated figures, and is actually quite funny. I don't want to make the series sound light-hearted, though. While it does satirize many elements of traditional British social life (everyone's favorite), much of Patrick's story is intensely upsetting. That's part of what makes it so good.

What to say of Patrick Melrose? Much has been written of his acidic humor, his childhood traumas and persisting fear that he will commit the sins of his parents. I found the first few books, especially the first, captivating in their awful family dramas. I regret that I later became exhausted by Patrick/St. Aubyn's longwinded and occasionally solipsistic self-analysis, which seemed to dominate 40% of the text in the last three novels (the other 60% dominated by Patrick's analysis of his interlocutors). I regret my exhaustion because now that it is gone I miss it. In retrospect it was a pleasure to hear him speak; to read the novel was to listen to a man with a magnificent control of English and an acerbic wit welcoming you into his head. Patrick's story has many of the themes that I like in literature: infidelity, mid-life male divorce, fear of being like one's parents. The dialogue is among the sharpest and most entertaining of any novel or set of novels I've read. Somewhere in the fourth novel, though, I remember wondering if there are better ways to tell the story of Patrick. Or, rather, shorter ways. I think of Junot Diaz's Yunior, who is perhaps not so different from Patrick: plagued by childhood traumas, guilty of infidelity, cynical about human relationships (with one or two really good ones, like Patrick's with Johnny), addictive in personality, and, finally, a man alone in the middle of life, searching for a kind of escape from his cycle of mistakes. With Yunior, however, we are treated only to the occasional self-reflection, rather than the endless revisions of Patrick. Most of what we see is the mistake-making process, filtered through Yunior's tough, soft-spoken, earnest voice. It is reductive to say that Diaz "shows not tells" while St. Aubyn "tells not shows," yet there is something to be said about the different ways the two tell a similar story. I regret that I prefer Yunior's earnest, concise speech, because I know that I'm missing something fundamental to Patrick's story, which is his voice. (Indeed, is Patrick's voice its own character in that story?) But I would be lying if I said that I enjoyed it more than Diaz's Yunior. I would like to read this again.

An astounding five-novel journey through the life of Patrick Melrose and the disintegration of Britain's upper class. Every page serves up a gem of wit, warmth or wisdom; sometimes all three in all. Immensely pleasurable to read; St. Aubyn's genius prose describes better than maybe anything I've ever read how it feels to be alive, how thoughts link up and wash over you, and how exhausting it is to live with a mind that chatters away and that never stops. These novels are absolute masterpieces, all of them, in very different ways. With these five novels, Edward St. Aubyn guides us through life, with all its complexities and paradoxes. I loved them, I loved the characters and I can't wait to read them again sometime; these are some of the funniest, warmest and loveliest books I have ever had the sheer pleasure to read.

Quite an affecting experience, to dive in and commit to these five novels! St Aubyn's novels follow Patrick Melrose's story of abuse, addiction, and recovery from childhood into early middle age against the backdrop of English high society. Harrowing and funny, yet moving and genuine, the novels are best read together, each building off and referencing one another often, so it's beneficial to read them in quick succession. Biting and profoundly clever dialogue throughout, and laced with psychological turmoil as this clever and ultimately sympathetic character of Patrick Melrose seeks to overcome his horrific experiences early in life. Not my usual genre, and many of these characters were despicable human beings, but the incredible writing style impressed the hell out of me, and I ultimately came to love Patrick and root for him.

Minor, flat. I do not recommend reading all five novels at one stroke, which I did, thinking at first, that the easy, translucent writing will easily carry me through the short books to the very end, only to find out that the prose gradually changes in style and weight so as to smother the reader under it by the very last book. And it was to be expected, as the whole undertaking is to hammer out a semblance of life from a semblance of story as broken and incidental as is the narrator's persona. A shrapnelled life requires a shrapnelled writing and reading as well, otherwise a lot of thought put into the prose gets trampled under and the whole readerly experience undeservingly slugs behind. Dish out wisely.

Imagine that This Be The Verse by Philip Larkin (https://www.poetryfoundation.org/poem...) took 5 books and quite a lot of characters, all of whom tend to know the love only in its most unbalanced, crippled states, all of whom are suffering from mistakes of their parents and passing new mistakes on to their children. I think if it was twice shorter I would love it. Because the language is beautiful, the sense of humour is sharp and the pain described in this book is blunt and inevitable. But I just couldn't force myself care about half of the characters, let alone feeling sorry or happy for them. I had to skip the whole pages because it was becoming extremely boring but I still wanted to know what happened to those few I was actually interested in.

For the first time, 
all five books in the Patrick Melrose series are collected in a single edition:

Acclaimed for their searing wit and their deep humanity, this magnificent cycle of novels - in which Patrick Melrose battles to survive the savageries of his childhood and lead a self-determined life - is one of the major achievements in English fiction.
